facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 118 to 121 of 1952 filed in Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeals under article 133(1)(c) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals under article 133  1   c of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 10th August, 1950,

facts.text: Appeals from Judgment and Order dated 10th August 1950 of High Court of Judicature, Punjab at Simla by Khosla and Kapur JJ.

anchor.surface_text: from the Judgment and Order dated the 10th August, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature, Punjab at Simla  Khosla and Kapur JJ.  in Civil

facts.text: High Court proceedings in Civil Miscellaneous Nos. 256, 260, 261 and 262 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Miscellaneous Nos. 256, 260, 261 and 262 of 1950 . Dr. Balkshi Tek Chand  T. N. Sethi, with him  for the appellants.

facts.text: Partnership firm K.S. Rashid & Son started on 5th May 1934 with partners K.S. Rashid Ahmed, Saeed Ahmed and Mrs. Zafar Muhammed.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that a partnership firm carrying on business under the name and style of K.S. Rashid Son was started on the 5th of May, 1934, the partners being three in number to wit K.S. Rashid Ahmed, Saeed Ahmed, his son, and Mrs. Zafar Muhammed,

facts.text: Mrs. Zafar Muhammed died on 7th January 1946, partnership dissolved.

anchor.surface_text: his mother Mrs. Zafar Muhammed died on the 7th of January, 1946, and as a result of her death the partnership stood dissolved.

facts.text: New firm K.S. Rashid & Son started on 8th January 1946 with surviving partners and Saeeda Begum.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately on the day following, that is to say on the 8th of January, 1946, a new firm was started bearing the same name, with the two surviving partners of the original firm and one Saeeda Begum, a daughter of K.S. Rashid, as the third partner.

facts.text: Central Government referred cases of firm and individuals to Income-tax Investigation Commission on 31st December 1947 under section 5 of Act XXX of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On the 31st of December, 71947, the Central Government referred the cases of this firm, as well as of the individuals companystituting it, to the Income-taxInvestigation Commission for enquiry and report under section 5of Act XXX of 1947,

facts.text: Authorised official under section 5(4)(3) appointed as respondent No. 2 started investigation.

anchor.surface_text: presumably on the ground that there had been substantial evasion of payment of income-tax in these cases. The authorised official appointed under section 5  4  3  of the Act, who figures as respondent No. 2 in all these appeals,

facts.text: Authorised official extended investigations to period subsequent to 31st March 1943, after which income-tax assessments were completed.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants companyplaint is, that companytrary to the provisions of the Act, he extended his investigations to a period subsequent to the 31st March, 1943, up to which date the income-tax assessment in all these cases was companypleted.

facts.text: Petition complaining about extension of investigation made to authorised official on 8th April 1949.

anchor.surface_text: A petition embodying this companyplaint was made -to the authorised official on the 8th of April, 1949, but numberorder was passed on the petition, as the Commission was expecting an early change of law in this respect.

facts.text: Law amended by Ordinance dated 5th July 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The law was amended by an Ordinance dated the 5th of July, 1949, but the appellants still companytended that the amendment was neither retrospective in its operation,

facts.text: Account books shown to official under protest.

anchor.surface_text: The account books, however, were shown to the official under protest.

facts.text: Three applications filed before Commission on 17th September 1949 regarding Mrs. Zafar Muhammed, Saeeda Begum, and new firm.

anchor.surface_text: On the 17th September, 1949, three applications were filed before the Commission, one with regard to the affairs of Mrs. Zafar Muhammed stating that numberinvestigation companyld take place in regard to her as she was already deadthe second with regard to the affairs of Saeeda Begum on the ground that she being a new partner and number having been assessed before, was number subject to the jurisdiction of the Commission while the third application was to the effect that the new firm, which came into existence on the 8th of January, 1946, companyld number have its affairs enquired into at all under the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Four miscellaneous petitions filed before High Court of Punjab in June 1950, C.M. Nos. 256, 260, 261, 262 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: After that, in June, 1950, four miscellaneous petitions were filed,  being C.M. Gases Nos. 259 to 262 of 1950  on behalf of the appellants, before the High Court of Punjab,

facts.text: Petitions prayed for writ of prohibition against Commission and authorised official.

anchor.surface_text: and the prayers made therein were of a three- fold character. It was prayed in the first place that a writ of prohibition might be issued to the Commission and the authorised official directing them number to proceed with the investigation of cases referred to the Commission under section 5 of Act XXX of 1947.

facts.text: Petitions prayed for writ of certiorari to quash proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The second prayer was for a writ in the nature of certiorari for quashing the proceedings already companymenced.

facts.text: Alternative prayer for revision under article 227.

anchor.surface_text: The third and the alternative claim was that the proceedings before the Commission might be revised under article 277 of the Constitution and suitable orders passed as the justice of the case would require.

facts.text: Rules issued by High Court on 25th July 1950 after report from Investigation Commission.

anchor.surface_text: Upon these petitions, rules were issued on the 25th of July, 1950, after a report from the Investigation Commission had been called for.

facts.text: High Court dismissed petitions on grounds of jurisdiction and special remedies under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: These companytentions found favour with the learned Judges who heard the petitions, and although they did number express any final opinion on the third point raised they dismissed the applications of the petitioners on the first two grounds mentioned above.

facts.text: Investigation Commission located in Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: the mere fact that the location of the Investigation Commission was in Delhi would number companyfer jurisdiction upon the Punjab High Court

facts.text: Petitioners are assessees within U.P. State.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the petitioners are assessees within the U. P State and their original assessments were made by the Income-tax Officers of that State.

facts.text: Appellants availed remedy under section 8(5) of the Act, reference made to High Court of Allahabad awaiting decision.

anchor.surface_text: it has been brought to our numberice that the appellants before us have already availed themselves of the remedy provided for in section 8 5  of the Investigation Commission Act and that a reference has been made to the High Court of Allahabad in terms of that provision which is awaiting decision.

facts.text: Judgment of Supreme Court delivered by Mukherjea J. on 22 January 1954.

arguments.claim: Punjab High Court lacks jurisdiction under Article 226 to issue writs because petitioners are assessees belonging to Punjab and mere location of Investigation Commission in Delhi does not confer jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents... It was contended in the first place that the petitioners being assessees belonging to P., their assessments were to be made by the Income-tax Commissioner of that State and the mere fact that the location of the Investigation Commission was in Delhi would not confer jurisdiction upon the Punjab High Court to issue writs under article 226 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Act XXX of 1947 being special nature creating new rights/liabilities, its remedies are exclusive and Articles 226/227 not available

anchor.surface_text: The second objection was that the Act itself being of a special nature which created new rights and liabilities, the remedies provided for in the Act itself for any breach or violation thereof were the only remedies which could be pursued by the aggrieved parties and article 226 or 227 of the Constitution would not be available to the petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: The law was amended by an Ordinance dated the 5th of July, 1949, but the appellants still contended that the amendment was neither retrospective in its operation, nor did it enable the authorised official to carry on his investigation beyond the 31st March, 1943.

arguments.claim: Article 226 confers wide powers on all High Courts; writs issue to authorities within territories by location

anchor.surface_text: This line of reasoning does not appear to us to be proper and we do not think that the decision in the Parlakimedi case is really of assistance... The Constitution introduced a fundamental change of law in this respect.

arguments.claim: Section 8(5) not necessarily exclusive remedy excluding Article 226

anchor.surface_text: the High Court relies upon the ordinary rule of construction that where the legislature has passed a new statute giving a new remedy, that remedy is the only one which could be pursued.

arguments.qualifiers: not necessary to express final opinion

arguments.claim: Article 226 discretionary; refuse if adequate alternative remedy available, as here under s.8(5)

anchor.surface_text: We think that it is not necessary for us to express any final opinion... the remedy provided for in article 226 of the Constitution is a discretionary remedy and the High Court has always the discretion to refuse to grant any writ if it is satisfied that the aggrieved party can have an adequate or suitable relief elsewhere.

holdings.text: The Punjab High Court has jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution to issue writs of certiorari or prohibition against the Income-tax Investigation Commission as it is located in Delhi within the territories in relation to which the High Court exercises jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the first contention raised by Dr. Tek Chand must be accepted as sound and the view taken by the Punjab High Court on the question of jurisdiction cannot be sustained. So far as the second point is concerned,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 226 confers wide powers on all High Courts; jurisdiction determined by territories and amenability of person/authority by residence or location within territories; distinguishes Parlakimedi case relying on Election Commission v. Venkata Rao.

holdings.text: The person or authority to whom a High Court issues writs under Article 226 must be within the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction, amenable by residence or location.

anchor.surface_text: The other limitation is that the person or authority to whom the High Court is empowered to issue writs must be within those territories and this implies that they must be amenable to its jurisdiction either by residence or location within those territories.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation of Article 226(1); Constitution fundamentally changed pre-existing law limited to chartered High Courts; all High Courts now have wide powers per Election Commission v. Venkata Rao.

holdings.text: The decision in Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakimedi does not govern jurisdiction under Article 226 as the Constitution introduced a fundamental change granting wide writ powers to all High Courts.

anchor.surface_text: This line of reasoning does not appear to us to be proper and we do not think that the decision in the Parlakimedi case is really of assistance in determining the question of jurisdiction of the High Courts in the matter of issuing writs under article 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-Constitution limits applied to chartered HCs only; Article 226 expands to all HCs without rigid limits; explained in Election Commission v. Venkata Rao.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide whether section 8(5) of the Income-tax Investigation Commission Act, 1947 provides the exclusive remedy excluding Article 226.

anchor.surface_text: We think that it is not necessary for us to express any final opinion in this case as to whether section 8(5) of the Act is to be regarded as providing the only remedy available to the aggrieved party and that it excludes altogether the remedy provided for

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter as alternative ground suffices; appellants already availed s.8(5).

holdings.text: Remedy under Article 226 is discretionary; High Court may refuse writ if aggrieved party has adequate alternative relief elsewhere.

anchor.surface_text: under article 226 of the Constitution. For purposes of this case it is enough to state that the remedy provided for in article 226 of the Constitution is a discretionary remedy and the High Court has always the discretion to refuse to grant any writ if it is satisfied that the aggrieved party can have an adequate or suitable relief elsewhere.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary rule of construction for special remedies considered but not decided; discretion applies where s.8(5) provides reference to High Court on questions of law.

holdings.text: Interference under Article 226 refused as appellants availed section 8(5) remedy with reference pending before Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the present case is concerned, it has been brought to our notice that the appellants before us have already availed themselves of the remedy provided for in section 8(5) of the Investigation Commission Act and that a reference has been made to the High Court of Allahabad in terms of that provision which is awaiting decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants pursued statutory remedy; discretionary jurisdiction not invoked at this stage.

precedents.citation: Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakitnedi 70 I.A. 129

anchor.surface_text: the well known case of Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakitnedi 1 . The question for companysideration in that case was, whether the High Court of Madras had jurisdiction to issue a writ of certiorari in respect of an order passed by the Collective Board of Revenue, as an appellate authority, in certain proceedings for settlement of rent between the Zamindar of Parlakimedi and the Ryots of certain villages within his estate situated in the district of Ganjam which was wholly outside the limits of the Presidency town of Madras.

precedents.case_name: Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakitnedi
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court of Madras did not have jurisdiction to issue certiorari to Board of Revenue for matters outside its jurisdiction even if Board located in Madras
precedents.cited_holding: the Supreme Court of Madras had no jurisdiction under the Charter to correct or control a country court of the East India Company deciding a dispute between Indian inhabitants of the Ganjam district
